  During the nearly three years between Dear Science and Nine Types of Light, the members of TV on the Radio worked on their own projects, which ranged from Tunde Adebimpe's role in Rachel Getting Married to Kyp Malone's Rain Machine, to David Sitek's move to Los Angeles and solo album, Maximum Balloon. When they and the rest of the band reconvened, Sitek's studio became their home base, and that west coast vibe sets Nine Types of Light apart from their other work. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s no coincidence that this is the groupÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sunniest set of songs; much of the angst and yearning that fueled albums such as Desperate Youth, Bloodthirsty Babes, and Dear Science are gone, replaced by a mellower focus on matters of the heart. Nine Types of Light unfolds at an unhurried pace, beginning with a pair of Malone songs that sound like they should close an album rather than begin it. That the album ends with Ã¢â‚¬Å“Caffeinated Consciousness,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ a brief check-in with the righteous fury the band usually displays, underscores how different Nine Types of Light is from what came before it. The band has always written about love with the same urgency and eloquence with which they tackle politics and other subjects, and Nine Types of Light is no exception. Adebimpe delivers two of the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s brightest moments with Ã¢â‚¬Å“You,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ a poppy meditation on how deceptive the heat of the moment can be, and the gorgeous Ã¢â‚¬Å“Will Do,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ a playful, seductive piece of soul-pop that ranks among TV on the Radio's finest moments. Indeed, the way the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s soul undercurrents rise to the fore, as on the psych-soul interlude Ã¢â‚¬Å“Killer Crane,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ may be the best and most exciting thing about Nine Types of Light. In many ways, the album feels like a working holiday for the band; even if itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not as explosive as some of their previous work, it shows that they can age gracefully and try new things at the same time.
